text: I will praise thee; for I am fearfully and wonderfully made: marvellous are thy works; and that my soul knoweth right well.
text_kjv: I will praise thee; for I am fearfully and wonderfully made: marvellous are thy works; and that my soul knoweth right well.
text_niv: I praise you because I am fearfully and wonderfully made;your works are wonderful,I know that full well.
text_esv: I praise you, for I am fearfully and wonderfully made.  Wonderful are your works; my soul knows it very well.
text_nlt: Thank you for making me so wonderfully complex!Your workmanship is marvelous — how well I know it.
text_msg: I thank you, High God—you're breathtaking!Body and soul, I am marvelously made!I worship in adoration—what a creation!
text_nasb: I will give thanks to You, for I am fearfully and wonderfully made; Wonderful are Your works, And my soul knows it very well.
context: Psalm 139 is a deeply personal and reflective psalm attributed to David, exploring God's omniscience, omnipresence, and omnipotence. It delves into the profound understanding of God's intimate involvement in the creation and sustaining of human life. In ancient Hebrew culture, there was a significant emphasis on the connection between the physical body and the spiritual soul. The concept of being 'fearfully and wonderfully made' was particularly poignant in a world where birth defects and infant mortality were common. The psalm stands in contrast to some ancient Near Eastern creation myths, which often depicted humans as being created primarily to serve the gods as slaves. This psalm, however, celebrates the divine artistry and purposeful design inherent in each individual. The language used, especially the word 'fearfully', highlights the awe and reverence with which the Psalmist views God's creative power. Furthermore, the idea of God 'knitting' (Psalm 139:13) the psalmist together in the womb emphasizes the intentionality and meticulous care God takes in forming each person. The overall tone conveys not only appreciation but also a deep sense of security and worth derived from being uniquely crafted by a loving and all-knowing Creator.
meaning: Psalm 139:14 is a powerful declaration of faith and a profound affirmation of human dignity. The phrase 'I will praise thee' establishes the verse as an act of worship, expressing gratitude and adoration to God. The confession, 'for I am fearfully and wonderfully made,' reveals a deep understanding of God's masterful creation. 'Fearfully' doesn't imply being afraid, but rather inspires awe and reverence in the face of God's power. 'Wonderfully' highlights the intricate complexity and beauty of the human body and soul. The Psalmist recognizes that the creation process is not haphazard but divinely designed and executed with extraordinary skill. 'Marvellous are thy works' extends this recognition beyond the individual to encompass all of God's creation. It acknowledges the splendor and brilliance evident in the natural world and in the entire cosmic order. The phrase 'and that my soul knoweth right well' emphasizes the personal conviction and internal certainty of this truth. It is not merely an intellectual assent but a deeply ingrained understanding that resonates within the psalmist's spirit. This intimate knowledge of God's creative power leads to profound self-acceptance and appreciation, recognizing that each person is a unique and valuable creation of God, fearfully and wonderfully made for a specific purpose. It refutes any notion of accidental or meaningless existence, emphasizing the inherent worth and dignity bestowed upon humanity by its Creator.
application: In today's world, Psalm 139:14 serves as a vital reminder of our inherent worth and purpose, particularly in a culture that often emphasizes external appearances and achievements. It challenges us to cultivate self-acceptance and to reject the negative self-talk and comparisons that can erode our self-esteem. This verse encourages us to appreciate the unique qualities and abilities that God has given us, recognizing that we are all fearfully and wonderfully made in His image. Practically, this means practicing self-compassion, acknowledging our strengths and weaknesses with grace, and celebrating our individuality. We can apply this truth by actively combatting body image issues and societal pressures that promote unrealistic standards of beauty. Instead of focusing on perceived flaws, we can shift our perspective to appreciate the incredible complexity and functionality of our bodies, marveling at the intricate systems that allow us to experience life. Furthermore, this verse calls us to extend this appreciation to others, recognizing the inherent dignity and worth of every individual, regardless of their background, abilities, or circumstances. This means treating others with kindness, respect, and empathy, valuing their unique contributions and perspectives. We should challenge prejudice and discrimination, advocating for justice and equality for all. Incorporating this verse into daily life involves making conscious efforts to cultivate a positive self-image, practice gratitude for our bodies and minds, and extend compassion to ourselves and others. By meditating on Psalm 139:14, we can deepen our understanding of God's love and creativity, and live more fully as the fearfully and wonderfully made beings He created us to be.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you with a heart filled with gratitude and awe. Thank you for creating me, fearfully and wonderfully made. I am amazed by the intricate details of your design, both in my physical body and in the depths of my soul. Forgive me for the times I have doubted my worth or compared myself to others. Help me to see myself as you see me – a unique and valuable creation, made in your image and for your purpose. Fill me with your love and acceptance, that I may extend that same love and acceptance to others. Guide me to use my gifts and abilities to glorify you and to serve your kingdom. May my life be a testament to your marvelous works. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Does 'fearfully' in Psalm 139:14 imply being scared of how God made us? No, 'fearfully' doesn't mean being frightened. It signifies awe, reverence, and respect towards God's power and skill in creating us. It's a sense of wonder at the intricate complexity of our being.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse

faqs.answer: How can I practically apply Psalm 139:14 when struggling with self-doubt and body image issues? You can intentionally focus on your strengths and unique qualities. Practice gratitude for your body's abilities, challenge negative self-talk, and seek support from trusted friends or a counselor.
faqs.question: Q2

faqs.answer: Does this verse imply that everyone is physically perfect? No, it emphasizes the inherent worth and dignity of every individual, regardless of physical imperfections. It celebrates the unique design and purpose God has for each person, flaws and all.
faqs.question: Q3

faqs.answer: How does this verse relate to people with disabilities or chronic illnesses? This verse affirms that even those with disabilities or chronic illnesses are fearfully and wonderfully made. Their lives have inherent value and purpose, and they are loved and cherished by God.
faqs.question: Q4

faqs.answer: Can this verse be used to argue against scientific understanding of human biology? No, Psalm 139:14 doesn't contradict science. It celebrates the divine artistry behind the biological processes that science seeks to understand. Faith and science can complement each other.
faqs.question: Q5
